introduction: Ruiqing is currently a Ph.D. student in the Department of Mechanical Engineering at the University of Hong Kong (HKU) (starting from Sept. 2020). He received his Bachelor’s and Master’s degrees in Building Environment and Energy Engineering from Chongqing University (CQU), China in Jun 2017 (with Best Bachler’s thesis award) and May 2020 (with outstanding Master’s thesis defense) respectively. In addition, he has exchange experiences as a visiting master in the School of Design and Environment (SDE) at National University of Singapore (NUS) from Dec 2018 to Jun 2019. He has been awarded 11 scholarships, 4 national awards, 2 Provincial awards as well as more than 20 University awards, including National Scholarship, Tanglixin Scholarship and Excellent Graduate Student of Chongqing. Ruiqing has multidisciplinary research interests in urban heat island mitigation, microencapsulation PCM, microPCM-concrete, nanofluid, heat transfer enhancement, geothermal heat exchanger, building energy efficiency, etc.

Xinjie joined Healthy Cities Lab at HKU as an MPhil student in Fall 2020. He obtained his B.Eng. degree in Building Environment and Energy Engineering at Southeast University in China. He is interested in microclimate, air quality, ventilation, and thermal comfort on both indoor and urban scales. Before he joined Healthy Cities Lab, he has performed several research projects on air quality, especially on indoor-outdoor air exchanges. He has also won the national first prize as team leader in the National University Student Competition on Energy Conservation and Emission Reduction. His research will focus on mechanisms and applications of vegetation-air interactions in the built environment. Apart from academic interests, Xinjie is also keen on Cantonese music and feels passionate to work in Hong Kong, which is such a metropolitan city and a unique field laboratory to study urban climate and air quality.
